awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Elucidating the Mechanism of Magnetogenetics for Remote Activation of Cell Function
awd_abstract_narration:
We are entering a new age of manufacturing where living cells are used to produce fuels, chemicals, and therapeutic proteins. Cell therapies offer the promise of enhancing a patient's natural immune system cells to fight cancer and other metabolic diseases.  These technologies are possible because of our ability to control the metabolism of cells. Most of the currently used control methods rely on chemical signaling, but chemical signals can also interfere with normal cell metabolism.  This project will develop a alternate biological control system that responds to magnetic signals. Research opportunities for undergraduates will develop a skilled STEM workforce. Outreach efforts will be multiplied through development of an 8-week summer workshop for K-12 teachers and high school students. 

Remote gene activation through static and alternating/oscillating magnetic fields will be evaluated for the control of protein expression in mammalian cells and cell cultures. The core hypothesis to be tested is that magnetic fields can induce the opening of ion channels upon co-expression of and mediation by ferritin tethered to the ion channel. The ferritin nanoparticles would serve as transducers, converting magnetic signals into physical ones that can activate a signal cascade. Magnetic fields offer much finer temporal and spatial control than is available using chemical signaling. The scope of the project and specific activities are threefold. First, elucidate the mechanism of static and oscillating/alternating magnetic field induced activation of ion channels. Second, tune sensitivity and responsiveness of magnetically activated ion channels by constructing genetic systems and controlling cell culture conditions to enhance ferritin properties leading to transient receptor potential (TRP) channel gating. Third, as a bioengineering application, use the genetically-encoded TRP channel-ferritin system to remotely control gene transcription and induce expression of key proteins involved in neurogenesis. The outcome of this study could be a foundation for designing methods to control cellular signaling, gene transcription, and protein expression/production for biomanufacturing applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The aims of this project were to 1) understand the mechanisms that allow magnetic fields to regulate the activity of cells genetically modified to express an ion channel tethered to ferritin and 2) use magnetic field induced cell activation to enhance neuron function.

 

Our studies used static (SMF), oscillating (OMF), and radio frequency (RF) alternating magnetic field (AMF) stimulation to modulate cell function in vitro in cells expressing a transient receptor potential vanilloid 1 (TRPV1) cation channel fused to ferritin. We used a combination of calcium imaging and measurement of a Ca2+-dependent secreted protein, alkaline phosphatase (SEAP) as a reporter to assess cell activation.

 

In collaboration with Prof. Dordick at Rensselear Polytechnic Institute (RPI), we showed that alternating magnetic field stimulation of ferritin-tagged ion channels induces local generation of a chemical signal, reactive oxygen species, that in turn opens TRPV1 channels. TRPV1 channel opening results in movement of calcium into cells and activation of neurons.  In addition, this mechanism also seems to contribute to cell activation when cells expressing ferritin-tagged TRPV1 channels are treated with static magnetic fields (SMF).

 

During the project, we generated modified forms of the ferritin-tagged TRPV1 channel to test if these alter how the tool is expressed in cells and its function. These include variants to increase channel expression at the cell membrane and change the calcium conductance. We tested these channels for their ability to activate cells using calcium imaging. The modifications did not significantly improve cell activation. 

 

We also developed and tested a new method of tethering TRPV1 channels to ferritin by generating a modified form of TRPV1 fused to ferritin-binding protein. The ferritin-binding protein recognizes both mouse and human ferritin which allows this tool to be used in a wide range of cell lines.  We validated the ability of the tool to activate cells in response to magnetic fields in a mouse and human cell line using calcium imaging. We also tested the ability of the tool to activate neurons and pancreatic insulin-producing cells. Static magnetic field treatment of insulin-producing cells expressing the TRPV1 channels tethered to ferritin increased insulin release in response to glucose. Next, we assessed the ability of the TRPV1 channel tethered to ferritin to regulate the growth of neurons in vitro. Neurons expressing the TRPV1 channel tethered to ferritin and treated with the magnetic field increased the growth of neural processes compared to magnet-treated neurons expressing a control protein.

 

These findings suggest that static and magnetic fields generate localized chemical signals that contribute to activation of ion channels tethered to ferritin. This tool can be used to enhance the activity of cells that use calcium for hormone release, such as pancreatic insulin-producing cells. Increasing activity in neural cells by magnetic field treatment of cells expressing ferritin-tagged TRPV1 channels increased growth of neural processes. These findings suggests that magnetic field enhanced cell activation may be a method for enhancing neuron growth.
